Since there seems to be an interest in RTTI, I think that the following will
be of interest

Using polymorphism design techniques eliminates all need for RTTI except in
certain system services like serialization.

No other class should ever have the urge to ask what subclass something is.
Instead, it should ask the subclass to do the relevant work in its own
unique way.

"Don't use RTTI" has almost nothing at all to do with whether or not your
tools happen to use RTTI under the hood.

Ordinary applications don't ever need to use RTTI or it's cousin the
introspection framework, and should steer clear of it.  If you are writing
system utilities like compilers, optimizers, testers, servlet/applet/bean
containers, etc., you might want to make use of the reflection and
introspection capabilities of the language.  These situations are rare.  So
rare, that outside EJB's and JUnit, I'm hard pressed to find a use for them.
